rxEdYmb0.question: The color identification of the contents of droppable containers and packages containing survival equipment should take the form of coloured streamers according to the following code:

options.text: yellow for medical supplies and first aid equipment.
blue for blankets and protective clothing.

ALRgdLBk.question: The color identification of the contents of droppable containers and packages containing survival equipment should take the form of coloured streamers according to the following code:

options.text: yellow for blankets and protective clothing.
blue for medical supplies and first aid equipment.

yFDvVj2k.question: You are flying over the NAT region when you intercept a distress call. You record the message, get a bearing on it from the ADF, and inform Shanwick control. The radio operator at Shanwick tells you to standby. What should you consider doing while awaiting instructions?

options.text: Proceed to the position given in the distress message.
Call your operator and advise him that you are now on SAR duty and will need to divert to nearest aerodrome at the end of your duty.
Descend to low level and carry out a surface search for ships.
Make a general call on 121.5 asking other airplanes to assist.

gcltvsKW.question: What is each contracting state of ICAO required to provide?

options.text: Facilities for SAR operations to be undertaken in its airspace.
Adequate radio navigation facilities for aeroplanes transiting its airspace.
Oceanic control facilities in oceanic areas adjacent to its territorial airspace.
Details of Aerodrome Operating Minima to each operator using its airspace.

uUOpjw4W.question: Alert phase is defined as follows:

options.text: A situation where an apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants.
A situation related to an aircraft which reports that the fuel on board is exhausted.
A situation related to an aircraft and its occupants are considered to be in a state of emergency.
An emergency event in which an aircraft and its occupants are considered to be threatened by a danger.

3gxTltj5.question: According to ICAO Annex 12, the search and rescue regions in which rescue coordination centres are established...

options.text: shall be next to each other but NOT overlap, and their boundaries can differ from State boundaries.
may overlap if the extent of the overlapping area has been agreed between States.
shall be next to each other but NOT overlap, and follow the delineation of the boundaries between States.
may overlap if the overlapping area does NOT exceed 50% of each search and rescue area.

e94jgYnz.question: What is the meaning of the ground-air visual signal 3?

options.text: We are not able to continue and we will return to base.

6QYqsI0B.question: Search and rescue on the high seas is conducted:

options.text: by the basis of Regional Air Navigation agreements.
by agreements of the ICAO committee.
by agreements of the EASA committee.
These areas cannot be served by SAR.

t21TmmMp.question: What do you do, if feasible, after receiving a distress message from an aircraft near your position?

options.text: Acknowledge the transmission, and begin to search the aircraft in distress.
Hold at your current position and coordinate the SAR operation.
Enter a holding pattern and await instructions.
Record the bearing of the transmission, and continue on your way.

5zVbU1oA.question: To which geographical areas is ICAO Annex 12 applicable to?

options.text: Over the territories of Contracting States and over the high seas.
Over Contracting States and Territorial waters.

G9oMbcKU.question: "A situation wherein apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants" is the definition for:

RHZtOBcr.question: Those portions of the high seas or areas of undetermined sovereignty for which search and rescue services will be established shall be determined on what?

options.text: On the basis of regional air navigation agreements.
Determined by EASA’s search and rescue committee.
Determined by ICAO’s search and rescue committee.
Those vast areas cannot be serviced.

1On2eAGz.question:
Three aircraft: (1), (2) and (3), arrive successively at ten minute intervals, overhead the scene of a recent aircraft accident.
(1) is unable to establish contact with the Search and Rescue Centre;(2) is able to contact the Search and Rescue Centre;(3) is a Search and Rescue helicopter.
The command of the situation is the responsibility of:

options.text: (1), then by mutual consent (2) and then (3).
(2), then by mutual consent (3) until the completion of operations.
(1), and then by mutual consent to (3).

1ou9mJ1Y.question: When an aircraft crashes in an area not owned by a certain state, who is responsible for carrying out SAR activities?

options.text: The one who is determined on the basis of regional air navigation agreements.
The state closest to the place of occurrence.

IpvnrLNB.question: Whenever a distress transmission is intercepted by a pilot-in-command of an aircraft, the pilot shall, if feasible

options.text: acknowledge the distress transmission and record the position of the aircraft in distress if given.
hold at the position and coordinate the SAR operation.
enter into a holding pattern and wait for instructions.
record the position of the transmission and proceed according to the flight.

OsQdC992.question: If you are the first one who arrives at an area where an accident has happened, before search and rescue services arrive:

options.text: enter into a holding pattern and wait for an SAR aircraft to arrive.
if possible take a bearing on the transmission.
record the position of the craft in distress if given and if possible take a bearing on the transmission.
record the position of the craft in distress if given.

options.text: We have found only some personnel.

options.text: We are not able to continue and we will return to base.

Tybu3GzN.question: One condition to initiate the distress phase is

options.text: the aircraft and its occupants are threatened by grave and imminent danger and require immediate assistance.
the aeroplane has been cleared to land but fails to land within five minutes of the expected landing time.
information has been received indicating that the operating efficiency of the aircraft has been impaired but not to the extent that a forced landing is likely.
the aircraft fails to arrive within 30 minutes of the ETA.

m7Ca4XDo.question: According to ICAO Annex 12, what does Rescue Coordination Centre mean?

options.text: An unit responsible for promoting efficient organisation of search and rescue services and for coordinating the conduct of search and rescue operations within a search and rescue region.

A unit performing distress monitoring, communication, coordination and search and rescue functions, initial medical assistance or medical evacuation, through the use of public and private resources, including cooperating aircraft, vessels and other craft and installations.
An unit retrieving persons in distress, providing for their initial medical or other needs, and delivering them to a place of safety.
A mobile resource composed of trained personnel and provided with equipment suitable for the expeditious conduct of search and rescue operations.

03dUShvT.question: If the first aircraft to reach the scene of an accident is not a search and rescue aircraft, what action must it take until the arrival of the first search and rescue aircraft?

options.text: Take charge of on-scene activities of all other arriving aircraft.
Overfly the wreckage every 10 minutes, searching for any surface-to-air visual signals.
Remain in the area, overflying the scene of the accident at a height of 1000 ft on a North-South heading.
Leave the area to avoid hampering subsequent search and rescue activities.

SAiVjl1s.question: How does a pilot confirm that he/she understood instructions from ground signalling during the daytime?

HemE3RuG.question: Consider the provisions in ICAO Annex 12 on air-to-ground signals. If survivors see an aircraft rocking its wings during the hours of...

options.text: daylight, this means that ground signals have been understood.
darkness, this means that ground signals have NOT been understood.
daylight, this means that ground signals have NOT been understood.
darkness, this means that ground signals have been understood.

record the position of the craft in distress if given.
if possible take a bearing on the transmission.

JMG2vSzJ.question: How are the search and rescue regions defined by the contracting states?

options.text: SAR regions shall not overlap, and neighboring regions shall be adjacent.
Each state defines its SAR, however, neighboring states cannot establish search and rescue services within a single SAR region.
SAR regions can overlap whenever it’s more efficient.
SAR regions can overlap, and neighboring states can establish search and rescue services within a single SAR region.

g0T6T98W.question: At night an aircraft observes a luminous signal requesting help. To indicate that he has received these search and rescue ground signals, the pilot shall:

options.text: switch his landing lights on and off twice or, if he/she is not so equipped, his/her navigation lights twice.

fly over the group of people in difficulty as low as possible.
transmit, by luminous Morse signal, a series of the letter "R" using his navigational lights.
